>> Yeah, thank you so much for being here

and we'll talk about what we've done so

places.
>> Yes. So, we will talk about some general

then we'll go into a toolbox for

So why play table digital twins? Um it
comes down to shifting expectations.
Some of us here remember the dialup
internet. Uh web 1.0 was mostly text and
images as you know. Then came web 2.0 uh
with social media and streaming and
video everywhere. And now the next
frontier is the spatial web with
immersive, interactive, and shared 3D
worlds and spaces. And online social
gaming platforms such as Fortnite,
Roblox, and Minecraft have already
shaped how Gen C and Gen Alpha see the
digital world today. For them,
interactivity and being immersed isn't
optional. It's the baseline.
uh what they do in games today uh they
will expect in education, city planning,
public engagement and so on in tomorrow
and at the same time as this is going on
uh cities all over the world are uh
investing in creating digital twins. Uh
most of these twins end up locked away
in uh GIS systems and uh academic silos.
And our question is simple. If these
twins already exist, why not make them
public, interactive, and playable?
And this is where the power of play
comes in. Play isn't just for kids. It
it's about lifelong learning and
connections. Play is joyful. It's social
and active.
And uh it helps us think, grow, and feel
together. And we all share the same
planet, right? So why not combine the
power of play with realworld places and
learn from that while at the same time
having fun and and connecting with each
other. And this is the foundation of our
project that we call playable places
that we're going to talk about today.
And to be able to play with reality in
the digital space, you first need to
capture it. And there are a lot of
different tools in the toolbox like
photoggramometry, gshion splatting, geod
data like open street map, we have
photorealistic 3D tiles from Google and
also generative AI etc. And all of these
tools each have their own pros and cons.
And if you get to know them, you can
know how to combine them for the best
results.
So let's start with the classic
photoggramometry. It's like the OG of
the bunch.
basically means you start with images or
videos as an input and the app
calculates a point cloud to create a
textured mesh. And the key concept here
is something called structure for a
motion which basically is trying to find
common points in overlapping images to
calculate how the camera has moved and
thereby understand the 3D scene. Uh we
usually work with reality scan. It was
the app formerly known as reality
capture. It's a very solid tool and it's
widely used across industries.
The main pros with photoggramometry is
that you get an actual physical mesh
that you can work with in your scene for
shadow shadows and lighting and it's
also easy to generate collisions from
these meshes. Uh, it's a very
established pipeline, so it works for
large areas and it also exports to a lot
of common formats, so it's easy to find
compatibility with other 3D
applications.
There are, of course, some cons. It
struggles with motion blur and
reflective surfaces. Also, transparency
and fine details can often get distorted
with photoggramometry. And then it can
also take a lot of time to uh optimize
after capture and do a lot of manual
labor with small details that get
distorted and so on. Since the lighting
and shadows are baked into the
photoggramometry, it's it's hard to to
relight it afterwards if you want to
work with dynamic lighting. So that's
that's an limitation. And also since
you're working with image textures,
there's usually also um resolution
limitations when you put it in other
applications.
So, it's a robust and powerful tool, but
not always the most efficient uh way to
go for every case, especially when you
want when you want to get close to the
subjects. That's also usually where you
ran in ran into some problems.
There's another method that's still
bleeding edge, but more and more
becoming a standard part of the toolbox.
It's called gshian splatting and it
takes the same input as photoggramometry
that is videos and and images and it
also uses structure for motion to to
calculate the camera angles. But instead
of representing the scene as 3D
geometry, it creates these uh 3D
ellipsoids called splats that they put
out in the 3D space like a point cloud
of these shapes and then it runs an
optimization over and over looking from
all of the the angles with photos trying
to match the best uh photoreal look. So
these splats have a position,
orientation,
color, opacity, and size more or less.
Uh and the big advantage here is the
detail. So the the splatty can handle
things like leaves, hair, reflections.
It can even do some view dependent
shading as well. But there are of course
trade-offs. This doesn't create a real
geometry. There's no physical geometry,
so you don't have easy collisions or
physics. And it's also limited when it
comes to editing. You can remove splats
from a scene, but you can't really like
deform these objects. And right now also
this works in Unreal Engine, but it
doesn't yet work in UEFN. So that's a
big uh limitation.
And in the projects where we worked, we
got access to some big gan splats shot
from from from the sky. Um, but we
wanted to see how would it look like if
we captured an object that's smaller, a
quite complicated object. A flower
bouquet has a lot of semi-transparent
surfaces, has motion blur. Uh, and we
want to see how could we make this look
if we shot 400 images with a DSLR with
some nice lighting. We had a soft box
above it and also we bounced uh two soft
boxes off the walls because you don't
want to get direct lighting into the
camera. And we did this uh like a test
comparing you have to the left you have
the gshian splat and to the right you
have a photoggramometry. So both are
built on the same input images but you
can see the difference in the details
and the color these two methods.
Another tool in the toolbox that's
really powerful is CCUM combined with
Google Earth data and Unreal Engine. So
what CSUM does is it streams the real
world in 3D into your application and it
it's built on a grid tile system. So it
only loads what's visible to the player
at that moment. And this is very useful
for big games, simulations, XR
applications, and also digital twins.
And since there's an official Unreal
Engine plugin, there's nice support with
with Unreal. And you can also there are
some pre-made data sets, but you can
also add your own data sets. You can
upload them to Cian, which is their
cloud-based service. Right now that only
works with uh with meshes, but I think
they're planning to integrate caution
splats as well in the future. And one of
these pre-made data sets you have in
is Google's photorealistic 3D tiles,
which is basically Google Earth uh put
into Unreal Engine. And this actually
also includes collisions ready made. So
it's not just the visual parts, it's
actual geometry.
Right now it covers about 1,900 cities.
And if you're working with one of these
cities, you have a really good base to
build on. You don't have to start from
scratch.
It looks best from a distance. When you
get close to it, you're going to see
some limitations with artifacts. Cars
don't really look great. And you have
the the normal limitations of
photoggramometry with uh texture
resolutions and and so on.
>> Yes. And another tool in the toolbox is
OSM data or open street map. Uh often uh
referred to the Wikipedia of maps. Uh
and it's a global open data set built by
contributors worldwide with the building
footprints and roads and parks and
railways and points of interest of
different kinds. And it's basically the
backbone of a city, how a city is
structured. And the great thing about
OSM is the speed and the accessibility
and that it's very lightweight because
it's open data. Anyone can use it. For
us as developers, it's a quick way to
generate a simple and pretty accurate
geometry for layouts and collisions and
prototyping playable environments.
The downside is, of course, that it's
very basic and there's no textures.
there's missing details like roofs and
interiors and sometimes incomplete
height data but as a lightweight and
democratic starting point uh it's a
really powerful building block
and the last building block or maybe not
the last but anyway another one is uh
touch on is generative AI and this space
is as you know it's moving incredibly
fast and we're starting to see how it
can support the playable places um idea
we have in many different ways. Uh right
now AI is you really useful in early
stages uh for previsisualization
concept development when we can quickly
sketch out ideas and clean up messy
capture before investing a lot of time
in a project. It's also becoming a
powerful tool for asset generation,
whether that's textures, 3D objects, uh
audio and music, or even code. You can
also modify assets, uh optimize them,
upscale textures, remove artifacts, or
even change a scenes date, time, season,
or or even style. So imagine being able
to see versions of your city or your
place in summer, winter, or even uh in
the year 2050 with just a click of a
button.
Finally, um let's think about how AI can
add life to these environments. If
generative AI can make and optimize
assets, uh agents and smart embassies
are what makes the world feel alive. And
you can start simple with smart MPCs
that just walk around and add some
atmosphere
uh with conversational AI powered by

You can even talk to a character or why
not a building or something else in an
in an environment. in Unreal Engine that
goes further with learning agents such
as humans and crowds simulating city
life. Uh cars simulating traffic and
drones for instance delivering goods.
The value here is that these AIdriven
agents makes digital twins more dynamic
and closer to how a real city actually
behaves and it adds life to scenes which
is very powerful for training and
learning and also engagement of course.
So now we're going to dive into our case
study. And with that background of
capturing and generating reality in

this case and uh how we actually try to

south from Stockholm uh their digital
twin into UFN and Fortnite. This is
where our journey of making digital
twins playable really began and where we
learned how challenging and exciting it
can be to make a real place interactive.
The original story of this uh started in
early 2024.
We already knew that nor sharping had a
digital twin and as UFN developers, we
asked ourselves, what if we could bring
it into Fortnite and UFN? Could it work
technically? And could it even be made

from the municipality,
uh the science park, and the game

small by mentoring five high school

development experience. But they managed
to build a simple prototype of nor
shopping in in UFN which you see here.
They called it revive.
And the prototype was very basic. But it
proved that the idea had potential. We
couldn't or they couldn't I mean we just
mentored them uh get the actual digital
twin working uh at that stage. But it
gave us a spark to apply for innovation
funding and to dive deeper into uh
together with the municipality and the
university of Lyn Shopping to see uh how
we could continue this project and uh
that's when the real journey uh of
making digital twins playable began.
So what were the goals of this project?
First uh a physibility check uh could we
actually bring a city's digital twin
into Fortnite both technically but also
at a reasonable cost since we are
working with either universities or
cities. So the budget is important here.
Second to document the process so other

distribution and rights. If it worked,
how could it be shared? Could it be
shared through the marketplace fab.com,
a project website or uh some of the

channels? And what about license? Um
would it be a creative common license

And finally, the idea was to leave
behind a template that others could
continue to build upon
uh for for instance game jams or student
projects and also future playable cities
and the UFN is a great tool and one of
the advantages is that you get a lot of
functionality right out of out of the
box like multiplayer and multiplatform.
This is something that is default
enabled by default. You don't have to
worry about networking or compatibility.
This just works. It's also connected to
a truly global audience with millions of
players already playing Fortnite. And
for us as developers, UFN is also great
for rapid prototyping. And since it
comes with URC, Unreal revision control,
collaboration is really easy and it also
works for small teams.
On top of that, there's a huge library
of readym made gameplay devices. These
provide functionality like checkpoints,
timers, scoring systems, and interaction
mechanics. That's all the basics you
need to quickly test out ideas.
You also get access to Fortnite's
characters and cosmetics, which makes it
easier to create experiences that feel
familiar to a lot of players.
And with verse as a new programming
language, there's also more flexibility
for custom logic than there was before.
And finally, one of the most exciting
things that we see also is the coming
persona device, which gives you LLM
driven MPCs that you can actually talk
to. And we're thinking about this could
not just be uh talking to characters.
This could in theory also be talking to
having conversation with a building or a
statue or any object in your world. So
UFN is not just a game tool anymore.
It's an evolving into a platform for
building interactive social and now AI
powered experiences as well.
But of course there's also limitation.
Everything's not good. Uh and when it
comes to building these cities in
Fortnite that are based on
photoggramometry cautious planning, you
have limitations like storage limit. For
instance, you have 400 megabytes of
storage, which might seem okay, but when
you think about bringing cityscale
meshes into Fortnite, it becomes a
challenge. Also, there's a special uh
limitation for UFN that you can only
have 64 materials on a mesh, which can
also create challenges when working with
cities.
The textures limited to 2K. That's fine
for a building, but it's more
complicated when you're working with
larger areas. And since Fortnite has to
work on everything from a high-end PC to
a mobile device, you always have to
think about the lowest common
denominator device to get everything
working. It's not acceptable if it's
just working for the high-end device. It
has to work for all of the devices. And
of course, Fortnite has been around for
a few years, so there are some player
expectations and a lot of the players
are still combat focused. So if you want
to bring in new types of experiences,
you have to think about how do you
onboard these players and shift their
expectations.
Also, uh there's a wall around Fortnite,
so there's no external APIs that you can
so you can't work with real-time data
for driving simulations or
visualizations in Niagara, for instance.
There's no blue blueprint support and
currently there's no gian splatting
support either in UEFN.
And on top of the technical limitations,
we also had some constraints that are
non-technical. So the municipality said
no players shooting players and no
realistic weapons. So that was a
challenge as well for us to think about
uh when it came to data collection. We
started working with the the university.
We quickly realized that there's not
like one digital twin. There's a lot of
different versions that sit in different
places. There were more modern versions
at the university and also the
municipality also had its own version.
Some of these versions were
photoggramometry meshes. We had both a
more lowfi older version that was big

hi-fi mesh that was smaller in coverage.
U more details, but also more work to to
to clean up. Like for instance, you have
these windows here that would take a lot
of manual work to clean up. And that
this would make it harder to work with
this type of of budget.
We also had some gosham splats to test.
We knew that this route was a long shot
getting them into UFN, but we really
wanted to to try to get this work and it
was like almost working but not not the
whole way. So in the end we had to
abandon this idea of gion splats in UFN
at least for now. We might circle back
to that in the future. And also all of
the data was captured from the air from
it was plane data and drone data. And
that's good for top- down gameplay from
from a bit of a distance. But it's not
ideal for street level experiences if
you want to have players exploring
closer to the ground. So right from the
start, we had to make some choices based
on this and see what was actually
possible.
Uh, so when it came down to choosing the
version, we actually choose the more
lowfi mesh version, it wasn't the
prettiest option, but it was the most
practical choice.
The main reason was feasibility. This
would run on low-end devices, which is
really important if you want to have
accessibility and a broad reach, which
we did. And beyond that, it also came
down to the compromise between balancing
quality, the coverage area,
compatibility with UFN, and also the
sheer amount of work it would take to
clean things up because we wanted to
find a process that could work for other
cities as well. So, in the end, the
lowfi mesh version gave us enough of the
city to build a playable demo without
making the project impossible within the
scope.
Uh the next step was uh importing uh the
digital twin into UFN and this was a
very iterative process. There was not
like one version and then we imported
it. Uh we needed to do this multiple
versions to try out what was working and
what wasn't. So there was a lot of
importing and in the end the the version
we got working was in the SketchUp
format. Uh, and in the first run we
imported it to Twin Motion and then used
Datasmith to get it into Unreal Engine
and then we migrated it into UFN. So far
so good. But then we got this we hit
this limit with the 64 materials per uh
mesh. So that didn't work. Uh, so we had
to put it import it into Blender and
slice it up. So we had about we had this
um area we sliced it up in seven areas.
So each area would not have more than 64
materials and then we could export it as
an FBX from Blender and then we could
put it into UF and and that was working.
Uh but of course nothing is that easy.
Uh in this import process all the
materials and all the textures got
mismatched. So we had to find them all
164 materials and 164 textures and
manually uh reconnect them. That was a
bit of a grind but it worked. And in the
end, we got the city up and running
inside of UFM working nicely.
When we had this version inside of

dynamic trees that were moving in the

Fortnite devices to test out some

to get a different look and also added
verse code for gameplay logic.
Um, this wasn't was the goal wasn't to
to make a finished game, but to show
what was possible with this these
resources in this type of project. We
also did some internal tests that okay,
we have this one version of the city.
How would it look like if we would use

And then it was time to try what kind of

given our restrictions from the
municipality.
We tried a lot of racing games both in

Not everything of these ideas became a

but the point was to explore what was

Um, and since all of the textures and
all the meshes were from drone and
flight photos, we decided to focus on

Uh there are some things that are not at

And just to wrap things up, uh what we

places. Here are some key things that we

to be static. They can be open. They can

interactive, immersive, and playable.
Second, there's no single way to do

Uh third, the platform you choose
